WorkItem.Description:
In my recent project using PHPWord library, I found that all the east Asian characters appears in question mark or corrupted while latin characters appears fine. After checking the source code, I think this issue come with 2 reasons and can be fixed by just a little modification:

First, some source code call utf8_encode() to wrap the text before inserting, but some insert directly. So I removed all of the 2 utf8_encode() call. Details shown below:
-----
FILE: Section.php     LINE: 157
FUNCTION: PHPWord_Section::addText()     LINE: 1
     remove the utf8_encode() call
-----
FILE: Section/Table/Cell.php     LINE: 142
FUNCTION: PHPWord_Section_Table_Cell::addText()     LINE: 1
     remove the utf8_encode() call
-----
Caller makes sure the text parameter is in UTF-8 encoding.

Second, east Asian font style leak as below:
-----
FILE: Writer/Word2007/Base.php     LINE: 233 ~ 237
FUNCTION: PHPWord_Writer_Word2007_Base::_writeTextStyle()     LINE: 13 ~ 17
     add this line
     $objWriter->writeAttribute('w:eastAsia', $font);
-----
However, in the file Styles.php such an east Asian font style definition already exists at line 312 ~ 317.

After these 3 line modification, the east Asian characters appears correctly.

In addition, I suggest to provide a way to set all the 4 font type separately in order to achieve the best display / print effort for mixed text. For example, if the font parameter is string type, set all the 4 types of font to that; when it is an array with 'w:ascii', 'w:hAnsi', 'w:eastAsia', 'w:cs' keys, set the font name separately.
